refsection.title: DENSITY DATABASE MANIPULATION
refsection.para: In the event the .g file has an internal density database defined (or the user wishes to define such a database) the mater command provides a number of options.

To import a density file into the .g file, use the "load" subcommand. By default this will update and append to an existing database if present. To completely replace any pre-existing definitions in the database, first run the "clear" command. To write out the current density definitions to a file use the "write" command.

For manipulation of subsets of the data, the "get" and "set" commands are provided. get will return either one or a set of tuples matching the provided key. Without a type option the key will be checked against all entries in all density information - to specify what type of key to use provide one of the type options. For id and density keys, a matching tolerance may also be specified - for names, glob pattern matching is supported.

refsection.title: MAPPING MODE
refsection.para: The -m mode of operation accepts a density file in the style of the gqa command and uses that file (along with an optional mapping file that maps complex material names to names in the density file) to assign material_id properties to objects whose material_name attribute is defined in the density file (or, if a mapping file is provided, the material_name can be mapped to a density file entry.)

A mapping file, if present, should consist of one mapping per line, with two quoted strings separated by a space. The first name will be the original name, and the second will be the name that is found in the density file.

For situations where a file has material_id attributes but no names, the --names-from-ids option will accept a density file and assign material_name attributes to those objects whose material_id values are present in the density file. It will also update material_name if it already exists on an object but the object's material_id value disagrees with the density file definition.
